item.title: How to Find the Last Bounty in Ghost of Yotei (Master Bounty Hunter)
item.description:
Excluding the false bounties that introduce players to the game's weapon-wielding senseis, there are 31 bounties in Ghost of Yotei . Most bounties can be taken on from the bounty boards found at the game's inns and sizeable settlements, but there are a few that will need to be picked up from the Bounty Broker directly.

However, the bounties that players get from Kojiro can only be picked up once Atsu has completed a few of the other bounties in the region, with each area having its own set of targets. New bounties will occasionally be added to bounty boards, which can make finding the last few Ghost of Yotei bounties a little tricky.

How to Find the Missing Bounty in Ghost of Yotei

The fastest way to find the last few bounties is to fast travel to each of the five bounty boards and make sure that nothing new has been added. While you're there, you should also take a moment to speak with Kojiro just in case you missed that region's Bounty Broker quest.

In all likelihood, though, the bounty that you're missing will be Wayward Oni Raiders , which only shows up on the Oshima Coast bounty board once players have completed the Shiro the Swindler bounty in the Ishikari Plain area. If not, and all of the boards are empty, it's almost certainly one of the four Kojiro bounties.

Upon finding a new bounty board, players should pick up all of the bounty posters and then immediately fast travel back to the board to replenish it. This way, they can work on all of a region's bounties simultaneously rather than having to do them two or three at a time.

Locked Ghost of Yotei Bounties (Bounty Broker Quests)

As mentioned above, most regions have a special bounty that players can get by speaking with Kojiro after they've completed three of the other bounties in that region. The only other locked bounties are the two that are tied to Master Yoshida's Sensei Tale in Tokachi Range and the aforementioned Wayward Oni Raiders, which requires players to complete Shiro the Swindler beforehand.

Bounty Name

Location / Unlock Requirements

Smiling Yoshitomo

Check the Bounty Board at the Yotei Shadow Inn in the Yotei Grasslands

Crow Genzo

Check the Bounty Board at the Yotei Shadow Inn in the Yotei Grasslands

Check the Bounty Board at the Yotei Shadow Inn in the Yotei Grasslands

Check the Bounty Board at the Yotei Shadow Inn in the Yotei Grasslands

Check the Bounty Board at the Yotei Shadow Inn in the Yotei Grasslands

Soma the Condemned

Speak with Kojiro at the Yotei Shadow Inn in the Yotei Grasslands after completing three of the other Yotei Grasslands bounties

Blue Yamauba

Check the Bounty Board at the Ishikari Market in the Ishikari Plain

Bloody Strings Hachibee

Check the Bounty Board at the Ishikari Market in the Ishikari Plain

Toshi the Torch

Check the Bounty Board at the Ishikari Market in the Ishikari Plain

Eijiro the Ruthless

Check the Bounty Board at the Ishikari Market in the Ishikari Plain

Check the Bounty Board at the Ishikari Market in the Ishikari Plain

Shiro the Swindler

Speak with Kojiro at the Ishikari Market in the Ishikari Plain after completing three of the other Ishikari Plain bounties

Iron Chuta

Check the Bounty Board at the Huranui's Rest Inn in Tokachi Range

One-Eye Moritaka

Check the Bounty Board at the Huranui's Rest Inn in Tokachi Range

Old Lady Yae

Bear Man Chikatoshi

Inokichi the Hungry

Complete The Way of the Odachi Sensei Tale in Tokachi Range

Black Night Kubo

Check the Bounty Board at the Red Crane Inn in Teshio Ridge

Inagawa the Gambler

Speak with Kojiro at the Red Crane Inn in Teshio Ridge after completing three of the other Teshio Ridge bounties

Eagle Eye Kondo

Check the Bounty Board at the Matsumae Residences in the Oshima Coast area

Iwa the Beautiful

Check the Bounty Board at the Matsumae Residences in the Oshima Coast area

Tadaaki The Terrible

Check the Bounty Board at the Matsumae Residences in the Oshima Coast area

The Last Brother

A Brokered Trust

Speak with Kojiro at the Matsumae Residences in Oshima Coast after completing three of the other Oshima Coast bounties

item.title: Best Games Where You Can Build And Command A Powerful Navy
item.description:
A navy is more than just a collection of ships. It's strategy. It's firepower. And it’s a healthy dose of pure, unadulterated swagger, all rolled into one glorious fleet. These are the games that let players do it all: design their own warships from the keel up, engage in tense, cat-and-mouse naval battles, or just relive some of history's most epic conflicts on the high seas.

Whether fans prefer the satisfying crunch of a ship-to-ship broadside, the cold, clinical tension of a modern missile duel, or a glorious sandbox where their own imagination can build the ultimate dreadnought, these are the titles that give the chance to feel like a proper admiral, with the fate of nations hanging on their every single order.

Sid Meier's Pirates!

The Original, and Still Untouchable, High Seas Sandbox

Sid Meier's Pirates!
7.0 /10
Released
November 22, 2004

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Alcohol Reference, Mild Language, Mild Violence, Suggestive Themes
Developer(s)
Firaxis Games
Platform(s)
iOS, PC, PSP, Xbox (Original), Xbox 360, Wii
Powered by

Few games have ever managed to capture the pure, swashbuckling romance of the Age of Sail quite like this one. Players are not just controlling a ship, but enacting a force of nature, roaming the beautiful, sun-drenched Caribbean as a privateer, capturing entire towns, hunting for buried treasure, and building a mighty armada that can challenge the Spanish Main itself, all while trying to woo a few governors’ daughters on the side.

Every choice made, every ship captured, feels like another step on the journey to becoming a legendary captain. The sheer, unbridled freedom to just live a swashbuckling life and command ships of every conceivable size is exactly what makes Sid Meier’s Pirates! endure as one of gaming’s great, timeless naval adventures.

Atlantic Fleet

Where Submarines, Destroyers, A nd Tense Duels Reign Supreme

Atlantic Fleet
Strategy
Simulation
Systems
Released
February 25, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Developer(s)
Killerfish Games
Platform(s)
PC, Android, iOS
Powered by

Atlantic Fleet takes a much slower, more methodical, more tactical approach to naval warfare. Set during the brutal naval campaigns of World War II, it puts players in command of either Allied or Axis forces in tense turn-based engagements where every single torpedo, every single depth charge, counts. The game's incredible focus on historical accuracy makes every hard-won victory feel so incredibly satisfying.

Its campaign mode lets players gradually build a powerful navy through hard-won strategic victories, forcing them to choose which precious vessels to bring into battle and, more importantly, when to risk them. There's nothing quite like the tense, beautiful satisfaction of landing a perfect, crippling shot on an enemy cruiser after carefully calculating a firing solution.

Ultimate Admiral: Dreadnoughts

Build Your Own Perfect, Glorious Warship

Ultimate Admiral Dreadnoughts
Real-Time Strategy
Simulation
RPG
Indie Games
Systems
Released
January 25, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Platform(s)
PC
Powered by

If players ever dreamed of designing their own battleship, down to the very calibre of the main guns, then Ultimate Admiral: Dreadnoughts is where those dreams become a glorious, steel-plated reality. The game’s ridiculously robust ship designer allows tweaking everything, from armor layouts and engine power to weapon placements, until a creation feels like the player's very own, perfect, floating fortress.

And the battles are these large-scale, slow-burning affairs, giving plenty of time to sit back and watch the custom glorious behemoths actually perform in battle as players outmaneuver and outgun the enemy fleets. Watching custom-built dreadnoughts just tear through the enemy lines is the ultimate reward for the hours of meticulous naval engineering.

From the Depths

Where Pure Creativity Meets Unpredictable Chaos

From The Depths
8.0 /10
Released
August 7, 2014

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
nr
Developer(s)
Brilliant Skies
Platform(s)
PC
Powered by

Part simulator, part sandbox, From the Depths is just as much about engineering as it is about combat. And players can build absolutely anything that floats, or flies, or even goes into space. F rom realistic, modern battleships to the most absurd, experimental craft, and then players can take their glorious creations into massive naval wars.

Its voxel-based construction system allows for wonderful levels of customization, which means fans can create a fleet that feels truly, uniquely theirs. And there is just an incredible sense of wonder when a bizarre, over-engineered monstrosity actually works, and begins to dominate the seas.

Sea Power: Naval Combat in the Missile Age

Modern Warfare at Sea

No broadsides here. This is the cold, tense, terrifying world of modern naval warfare. Set against the tense backdrop of a Cold War that's gone hot, Sea Power trades the romance of cannons for the cold, clinical reality of long-range missile duels and sonar pings. It's a highly detailed, incredibly deep simulation of modern naval combat, a world where positioning and the ability to detect the enemy are often so much more important than raw firepower.

Commanders have to coordinate everything: their aircraft, their submarines, their surface vessels across huge, wide-open ocean maps, turning every single battle into a mix of deep strategy and a high-stakes game of poker. One single, well-timed missile strike can decide an entire conflict.

War on the Sea

The Entire Pacific, Right In Your Hands

War On The Sea
Simulation
Real-Time Strategy
Systems
Released
February 2, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
m
Platform(s)
PC
Powered by

This game is a love letter to the classic naval sims of old, letting players relive the entire, sprawling Pacific Theater of World War II. Players will manage precious supply lines, position task forces on a grand, strategic map, and then take direct, personal control of their ships in these real-time battles that feel wonderfully cinematic in their scale.

Every single decision has real, tangible weight, from which islands to reinforce to when to commit the fleet to a decisive, all-or-nothing engagement with the enemy. Slowly, painstakingly, players can assemble a naval juggernaut that is capable of dominating the seas, and that journey is both deeply strategic and incredibly rewarding. A must-play for fans of proper, old-school naval command.

item.title: How to Change the Time of Day in Ghost of Yotei (Speed Up Time)
item.description:
The story of Ghost of Yotei takes place in a living, breathing world. Although the game lacks changeable seasons like the ones found in Assassin's Creed Shadows , it does have a day-night cycle, which can have a fairly significant impact on the way that certain tasks and side quests go down.

In fact, there are one or two instances where players will only be able to complete a quest at nighttime, which is why learning how to change the time of day in Ghost of Yotei can be important. Thankfully, the process is relatively straightforward, requiring only a couple of button clicks.

How to Change the Time of Day in Ghost of Yotei

To change the time of day, players simply need to go to a campsite and sleep . They can go to an existing campsite to do this or set up a new camp by holding left on the D-pad while in an open section of the map. While sitting at a campsite, selecting the Sleep option will allow them to sleep until morning or sleep until night . Alternatively, they can do things the old-fashioned way and wait around for the time of day to change by itself.

There are certain areas where it is impossible to change the time of day, including the titular Mount Yotei. Fast traveling to one of these areas during the nighttime will automatically revert to daytime.

When to Switch to Nighttime in Ghost of Tsushima

There are a handful of Ghost of Yotei bounties that require players to search an area at night, but these aren't the only times when it's beneficial to change the time of day. For those who enjoy taking the stealthy approach, liberating Yotei 6 camps can be a whole lot easier under the cover of darkness, so it's well worth taking a moment to switch a night before sneaking in. Conversely, exploring the map is arguably a lot easier during the daytime, and a lot more awe-inspiring to boot, so sleeping until morning can also be beneficial at times.

item.title: Best Open-World Games With No Real Objective
item.description:
Open-world games are quite freeing, as they often give players a lot to do and see. However, there are still a lot of things that can guide players in a certain direction. For example, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a great game that is all about Geralt trying to find Ciri, making that goal a pressing concern. Players don’t have to make a beeline to find her, but they may feel compelled.

That’s not a bad thing, but for those who want even more choice in their open-world adventures, these open-world games don't have one specific main objective to track , giving players little reason to follow a specific goal other than to explore and have fun.

Minecraft

The Ultimate Goal Is To Have Fun

Minecraft
191
9.0 /10
Released
November 18, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Fantasy Violence
Powered by

In Minecraft, players will create a Seed when they start a game, and then they will be loaded into their own customized world. Players can start farming for materials right away, and there’s not a single drop of story in the game other than some deep lore for anyone who wants to dive in and track it down.

Build a farm, dig a cavern, recreate a giant city or a real-world landmark, fight monsters at night, and so on. Alone or with friends, the possibilities in Minecraft are endless, but any goals to chase are entirely of the player's choosing.

Elden Ring

Survival Is Your Goal

Elden Ring
10 /10
70
9.1 /10
Released
February 25, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Powered by

FromSoftware’s games rarely have clear-cut objectives other than to explore and survive through a series of bosses in twisting interconnected worlds. Elden Ring similarly didn’t have a large overarching plot, but this time, FromSoftware decided to create an open world full of danger for players to explore.

There’s not much in terms of crafting or chill activities in Elden Ring , but players can fight enemies and bosses at their leisure without much linearity present. Certain areas can't be accessed until other areas have been explored, but odds are that exploration will happen naturally as players wander through the world. For those having trouble, as it is a challenging game, there is co-op available.

Fallout 76

Try And Make The Apocalypse More Livable

Fallout 76
5 /10
46
8.1 /10
Released
November 14, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Drug Reference, Intense Violence, Strong Language, Use of Alcohol
Powered by

Fallout 76 doesn't start with a big story setup, unlike most entries in the Fallout series. Instead, players just start exploring, killing mutants, and crafting almost from the outset. With consistent updates, Bethesda added more story quests, but they’re still not a central part of the experience.

Fallout 76 was made to give players even more freedom than the previous Fallout entries, unburdened by goals of finding a missing child, a missing father, or seeking revenge. That makes it a great entry to start with, plus there is co-op, so some friends can come along for the ride.

Sea Of Thieves

Sail With Your Mates

Sea of Thieves
7.7 /10
Released
March 20, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Crude Humor, Use of Alcohol, Violence
Powered by

Sea of Thieves is a pirate simulator more than it is a pirate action game. Over the years, there have been more objectives and areas to explore introduced via updates, but it’s another example of a game that is open from the start, and one where multiplayer is almost mandatory.

It is possible to sail alone, but a full crew of friends makes traversing the ocean a more enjoyable experience. Sing sea shanties, swashbuckle enemies, or look for treasure like a true pirate. There are no rules on the high seas.

No Man’s Sky

Travel The Universe

No Man's Sky
7 /10
69
9.3 /10
Released
August 9, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Fantasy Violence, Animated Blood
Powered by

No Man’s Sky is like Sea of Thieves , except instead of exploring the vast seas, players will sail through an endless galaxy in their spaceship. They can travel to a near infinite number of planets, each one different from the last.

There is combat, but things are generally more chill if players accept the rules dictated by a galactic council. Mine for crafting materials, scan weird creatures to build a database, or make a home for others to come and visit. No Man's Sky is a game that players can approach as they see fit, be it by chasing a goal or settling down on a brand-new planet.

Pokemon Legends: Arceus

No Badges In Sight

Pokemon Legends: Arceus
9 /10
18
7.4 /10
Released
January 28, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E for Everyone: Mild Fantasy Violence
Powered by

Most mainline Pokemon games put forth a specific goal of gathering Gym Badges and collecting Pokemon to be the very best. While Pokemon Legends: Arceus borrows some mechanics typical of the mainline games, it is first and foremost a Pokemon spinoff.

Players can progress through the story, but there’s not much emphasis placed on it. Instead, they can just as easily roam big open-world biomes to catch and fight Pokemon in real time. Whether players want to catch Pokemon or craft Pokeballs, there are dozens of activities to take on.

Palworld

Create A Pal Army

Palworld
148
8.7 /10
Released
January 19, 2024

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Violence
Powered by

Palworld is a Pokemon -like experience except with even more freedom on offer, and the monsters here are called Pals. There’s no story setup, and players are dropped into a world with just a list of objectives they can follow to unlock mechanics, or they can ignore those specific tasks and just play.

That includes catching Pals to ride, use as weapons, use as battle companions, or put to hard labor. It seems like Game Freak and Nintendo could learn a thing or two from Palworld , and it may be exactly where the idea for Pokopia came from.

Infinity Nikki

Jump Up And Look Good

Infinity Nikki
35
8.9 /10
Released
December 5, 2024

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen // Blood, Violence
Powered by

Infinity Nikki is a free-to-play game about the titular Nikki, who wants to become a fashionista. While the initial premise follows a story, and there are story quests to tackle to help unlock new content, the game doesn’t push players in that (or any) direction.

Instead, they can explore the world and look for upgrades on their own to craft new outfits. Some of the best content is locked behind a paywall, as this is a gacha-based game, but players can get plenty of enjoyment out of Infinity Nikki without spending a single dime.

item.title: Best Games That Make You Feel Like A Powerful Telekinetic
item.description:
There’s something great about m oving objects with nothing but the sheer, focused power of your mind. Games have always dabbled in the idea of psychic power, of course. But then there are the special ones. A select few titles that go so much further, the ones that truly, genuinely make you feel like you could rip reality itself apart at the seams with your own willpower.

These games don’t treat telekinesis as just a side-ability; it takes center stage. Whether you’re hurling screaming enemies into walls, twisting the very environment into a weapon, or just bending entire battles to your psychic will, these are the six games that get it right.

Control

The Glorious Bureaucracy of Telekinetic Power

Control
9 /10
7.6 /10
Released
August 27, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ // Mature: Blood, Strong Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Remedy Entertainment
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, PS5, Switch, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Xbox One
Powered by

Office desks. Filing cabinets. Fire extinguishers. In the world of Control , these are not mundane, everyday objects. They are lethal weapons. And Jesse Faden’s incredible psychic arsenal is exactly what makes Remedy’s paranormal thriller so ridiculously, intoxicatingly fun. The simple act of ripping a chunk of concrete from the floor and hurling it across a room at a monster made of pure hiss... it just never, ever gets old.

But what really makes it all resonate is how the story is so perfectly tied into that feeling. Jesse isn’t just some random person with superpowers; she's the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Control, a role that doesn't just grant her this incredible power, but also the immense responsibility for forces that are far beyond human comprehension.

Psi-Ops: The Mindgate Conspiracy

The Forgotten Psychic Powerhouse of the 2000s

Psi-Ops: The Mindgate Conspiracy
Third-Person Shooter
Systems
8.0 /10
Released
June 14, 2004
ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language

Developer(s)
Midway Games
Platform(s)
PC, PS2, Xbox (Original)
Powered by

This is one of those brilliant, mid-2000s action games that just felt years ahead of its time. You’re playing as Nick Scryer, a psychic supersoldier, and you can just toss enemy soldiers around like they’re weightless ragdolls. You can mind-control them and make them shoot their own allies. Or you can just... crush them with raw, invisible psychic force. It had gunplay, sure. But the real, pure, unadulterated fun came from just creatively, chaotically mixing your telekinetic powers with the environment.

Psi-Ops stands out, even today, for its sheer, gleeful willingness to just embrace the most absurd psychic chaos imaginable. Few things in gaming feel quite so mischievous as hurling an enemy into a conveniently placed pile of explosive barrels, or using your mind control powers to make them just casually walk off a ledge to their doom. A true cult classic that showed just how satisfying unrestrained telekinetic power could be, long before it became mainstream.

Star Wars: The Force Unleashed

Swinging Lightsabers With the Power of Your Mind

Star Wars: The Force Unleashed
10 /10
Released
September 16, 2008

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen // Violence
Developer(s)
LucasArts
Platform(s)
Nintendo DS, Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 2, PlayStation 3, PSP, Wii, Xbox 360
Powered by

In Star Wars: The Force Unleashed , players take control of Starkiller, Darth Vader’s secret, and ludicrously powerful, apprentice. And that means you’re not just wielding a lightsaber; you’re wielding the Force itself as a weapon of mass destruction. Enemies aren't just defeated; they're flung across rooms with bone-crunching force. Entire Star Destroyers are dragged from the sky. And legions of Stormtroopers are sent tumbling helplessly with a single, contemptuous flick of your wrist.

There’s a sheer, unbelievable scale of the destruction tied to your power. Every single battle just pushes the fantasy of being a Force prodigy with absolutely no limits, far beyond anything the films ever dared to show. It’s messy, ridiculously over-the-top, and gloriously, wonderfully indulgent. The ultimate power trip.

Scarlet Nexus

The Beautiful, Brainpunk Future

Scarlet Nexus
6 /10
7.3 /10
Released
June 25, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Alcohol Reference, Blood, Mild Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Bandai Namco Entertainment
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

Scarlet Nexus takes the core concept of telekinetic abilities and fuses it with some beautiful, fast-paced action. Both of the game's protagonists, Yuito and Kasane, fight with these incredible psychic powers that let them just grab cars, telephone poles, and chunks of debris from the environment and weave them into their flashy melee combos.

And where the game truly shines is in its unique, wonderful combat rhythm. Just hurling objects at your foes is only part of the flow. You're constantly swapping between your own telekinetic strikes and the unique abilities that you can borrow from your teammates, turning every single battle into this fast-paced, beautifully choreographed dance of pure psychic synergy.

Lucius

The Child Who Weaponized His Own Innocence

Lucius
Horror
Adventure
Systems
Released
October 26, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Developer(s)
Shiver Games
Platform(s)
Windows
Powered by

This is the dark side of telekinesis. A much, much darker side. In Lucius , you’re playing as the son of the devil, a creepy little kid who uses his burgeoning psychic powers not in open combat, but to engineer a series of grisly, "accidental" deaths within a sprawling, gothic mansion. Candles will just... fall over. Objects will move at just the right, or wrong, moment. And the mansion's poor, unsuspecting servants will meet a series of unfortunate, and often hilarious, ends, all thanks to your invisible, malevolent manipulations.

It’s a game that leans hard into horror rather than pure spectacle. The power here comes not from throwing boulders or wrecking armies, but from the subtle, terrifying control you have over the environment and the sheer dread that it creates. It’s a chilling, brilliant reminder of just how terrifying invisible power can be.

Galerians

When Telekinesis Becomes a Fight for Survival

Galerians
Action-Adventure
Horror
Systems
Released
March 29, 2000

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
m
Developer(s)
Polygon Magic
Platform(s)
PS1
Powered by

Galerians carved out its own unique, and deeply weird, space as a kind of horror-tinged, psychic thriller. You’re Rion, a young man who awakens in a strange medical facility with no memory, but with a whole suite of incredible psychic powers that let him hurl his enemies across rooms, set them on fire with pyrokinesis, or just fry their minds outright.

But these incredible abilities all come at a cost. A real, tangible cost. They drain his body, they cause him intense pain, and they often leave him completely vulnerable, which makes using them both an incredible thrill and a constant, terrifying risk. The deeply unsettling tone of the game just makes its telekinesis feel so dangerous, rather than liberating. A really unique and often forgotten, gem.
